description: From Middle English enticen, from Old French enticier (“to stir up or excite”), from a Vulgar Latin *intitiāre (“I set on fire”), from in- +‎ titiō (“firebrand (tool)”), from Proto-Italic *tītjō (“heating”), possibly from Proto-Indo-European *teih₁- (“to become hot, melt or to end”).

verbs.description: entice (third-person singular simple present entices, present participle enticing, simple past and past participle enticed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To lure; to attract by arousing desire or hope.
examples: I enticed the little bear into the trap with a pot of honey.
